newsitem.title: UK: Some analysts raise long-term BP forecasts.
newsitem.headline: Some analysts raise long-term BP forecasts.

text.p: Bullish comments from British Petroleum Co Plc at an analysts' meeting earlier today prompted some industry watchers to up their 1998 and 1999 profit estimates.
However none have yet decided on the level of the hike.
Others said they were also impressed with the bullish BP comments, but believed it was too early to have a detailed look at their forecasts beyond this year or next.
"It was a very good presentation, but it is a bit too early to look at 1998 and certainly at 1999, while 2000 is a long way away yet," said Rod McLean at ABN AMRO Hoare Govett.
"There might be some numbers moved up out to 1999, but that's not going to affect the market very much," he added, echoing a widely held view.
Shares in BP closed 7-1/2 pence lower at 703 after the oil giant drew a bright picture of notably its upstream operations.
BP said it could be producing 2.5 million barrels of oil equivalent per day within the next decade, an increase of a million barrels a day on current output.
The company said it expected to maintain production in its two established areas -- the North Sea and Alaska --, while pumping up more oil and gas in the Gulf of Mexico and South America.
New operations in the Caspian area, north and west Africa and Asia should also help lift production to two thirds above current levels, BP said.
"The production profile is growing at a slightly faster pace than I had originally thought," said Williams de Broe analyst Peter Hitchens.
BP also said that its target to improve underlying annual income by $1.5 billion a year could be met by 1999, which would be one year ahead of schedule.
But analysts said this was already widely expected after the company delivered $600 million towards that target in 1996.
"It was a very good story, very well told, but also very well known," said one analyst, who declined to be named.
